S6.T1.caption: Table 1. Learning setting of  Fed_BVA
S6.T1.table:
MNIST Fashion-MNIST CIFAR-10 CIFAR-100 (coarse)
# comms. 100 100 100 100
# clients (K) 100 100 20 20
fraction (F) 0.1 0.1 0.2 0.2
# epochs (E) 50 50 5 5
local batch (B) 64 64 128 128
# shared (nssubscriptğ‘›ğ‘ n_{s}) 64 64 30 60
# categories 10 10 10 20
references: For Fed_BVA framework, we use a 4-layer CNN model for MNIST and Fashion-MNIST, and VGG9 architecture for CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100. The training is performed using the SGD optimizer with a fixed learning rate of 0.010.010.01 and momentum of value 0.90.90.9. The trade-off coefficient between bias and variance is set to Î»=0.01ğœ†0.01\lambda=0.01 for all experiments. All hyper-parameters of federated learning are presented in TableÂ 1. We empirically demonstrate that these hyper-parameter settings are preferable in terms of both training accuracy and robustness (see the details of Fig.Â 4 - Fig.Â 6 in SubsectionÂ 6.5). To demonstrate the robustness of our Fed_BVA framework, we evaluate the deployed server model on the test set ğ’Ÿtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{test} against adversarial attacks FGSMÂ (Goodfellow etÂ al., 2015), PGDÂ (Madry etÂ al., 2018) with 10 and 20 steps (i.e., PGD-10, PGD-20). FollowingÂ (TramÃ¨r etÂ al., 2018; Wang etÂ al., 2019), the maximum perturbations allowed are Ïµ=0.3italic-Ïµ0.3\epsilon=0.3 on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST, and Ïµ=16255italic-Ïµ16255\epsilon=\frac{16}{255} on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 for both threat and defense models.

FedAvg 0.989Â±0.001plus-or-minus0.001{}_{\pm\text{0.001}} 0.669Â±0.009 0.267Â±0.014 0.980Â±0.002 0.491Â±0.067 0.158Â±0.074
FedAvg_AT 0.988Â±0.000 0.802Â±0.001 0.512Â±0.042 0.974Â±0.005 0.649Â±0.066 0.363Â±0.066
Fed_Bias 0.986Â±0.000 0.812Â±0.009 0.583Â±0.036 0.971Â±0.004 0.679Â±0.040 0.394Â±0.103
Fed_Variance 0.985Â±0.001 0.803Â±0.007 0.572Â±0.019 0.973Â±0.005 0.684Â±0.004 0.395Â±0.049
Fed_BVA 0.986Â±0.001 0.818Â±0.003 0.613Â±0.020 0.969Â±0.002 0.705Â±0.009 0.469Â±0.031
EAT 0.981Â±0.000 0.902Â±0.001 0.811Â±0.004 0.972Â±0.002 0.789Â±0.016 0.415Â±0.035
EAT+Fed_BVA 0.980Â±0.001 0.901Â±0.006 0.821Â±0.013 0.965Â±0.005 0.811Â±0.020 0.670Â±0.014
references: For the comprehensive experiments in TableÂ 2 and TableÂ 3, it is easy to verify that our proposed model outperforms all other baselines regardless of the source of the perturbed examples (i.e., locally generated like EAT+Fed_BVA or asymmetrically transmitted from the server like Fed_BVA). In this case, BV-FGSM (see Eq. (5)) is used to generate the adversarial examples ğ’Ÿ^ssubscript^ğ’Ÿğ‘ \hat{\mathcal{D}}_{s} during model training for robust federated learning. Compared to standard robust federated learning FedAvg_AT, the performance of Fed_BVA against adversarial attacks still increases 4%âˆ’13%percent4percent134\%-13\% and 2%âˆ’9%percent2percent92\%-9\% on IID and non-IID settings respectively, although Fed_BVA is theoretically suitable for the cases that clients have IID samples. In TableÂ 4, we observe a similar trend where Fed_BVA outperforms FedAvg_AT on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 (with 0.2%âˆ’10%percent0.2percent100.2\%-10\% increases) when defending different types of adversarial examples. Compared to the strong local adversarial training baseline EAT, we also observe a maximum 13%percent1313\% accuracy increase when applying its bias-variance oriented baseline EAT+Fed_BVA. Overall, the takeaway is that without local adversarial training, using a bias-variance based robust learning framework could outperform other baselines for defending FGSM and PGD attacks. When local adversarial training is allowed (e.g., the client device has powerful computation ability), using bias-variance robust learning with local adversarial training will mostly have the best robustness.

S6.T5.caption: Table 5. Accuracy of training with different loss functions and running time (second/epoch)
S6.T5.table:
Loss Clean Fed_BVA
BiasOnly VarianceOnly BVA
CE 0.588(38.13s) 0.763(47.58s) 0.759(63.46s) 0.776(63.67s)
MSE 0.601(39.67s) 0.711(65.03s) 0.711(162.40s) 0.712(179.60s)
references: Both cross-entropy (CE) and mean squared error (MSE) loss functions could be used for training a neural network model. In our paper, the loss function of neural networks determines the derivation of bias and variance terms used for producing the adversarial examples. We experimentally compare the CE and MSE loss functions in our framework. TableÂ 5 reports the adversarial robustness of our federated framework w.r.t. FGSM attack (Ïµ=0.3italic-Ïµ0.3\epsilon=0.3) on MNIST with IID setting. It is observed that (1) our framework with MSE has a significantly larger running time; (2) the robustness of our framework with MSE becomes slightly weaker, which might be induced by the weakness of MSE in training neural networks under the classification setting.

S6.T6.caption: Table 6. Comparison of training with BV-PGD and BV-FGSM
S6.T6.table:
Method IID non-IID
FGSM PGD-10 PGD-20 FGSM PGD-10 PGD-20
FedAvg 0.588 0.620 0.205 0.147 0.525 0.089
Fed_BVA(BV-FGSM)(BV-FGSM){}_{\text{(BV-FGSM)}} 0.776 0.793 0.570 0.670 0.695 0.472
Fed_BVA(BV-PGD)(BV-PGD){}_{\text{(BV-PGD)}} 0.757 0.840 0.632 0.659 0.784 0.575
references: Our bias-variance attack could be naturally generalized to any gradient-based adversarial attack algorithms when the gradients of bias Bâ€‹(â‹…)ğµâ‹…B(\cdot) and variance Vâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘‰â‹…V(\cdot) w.r.t. xğ‘¥x are tractable to be estimated from clientsâ€™ models learned on finite training sets. Here, we empirically compare the adversarial robustness of the proposed framework trained with bias-variance guided PGD (BV-PGD) adversarial examples and bias-variance guided FGSM (BV-FGSM) adversarial examples. TableÂ 6 provides our results on w.r.t. FGSM and PGD attacks (Ïµ=0.3italic-Ïµ0.3\epsilon=0.3) on MNIST with IID and non-IID settings. Compared to FedAvg, our framework Fed_BVA with either BV-FGSM or BV-PGD could largely improve the model robustness against adversarial noise. Furthermore, BV-PGD could potentially improve white-box robustness on multi-step attacks, but it is often more computationally demanding. As a comparison, BV-FGSM is more robust against single-step attacks.

S6.T7.caption: Table 7. Robust training with different strategies on MNIST
S6.T7.table:
Strategy IID non-IID
FGSM PGD-10 PGD-20 FGSM PGD-10 PGD-20
S1 0.745 0.743 0.450 0.529 0.677 0.433
S2 0.743 0.731 0.436 0.513 0.680 0.432
S3 0.730 0.704 0.400 0.495 0.657 0.380
references: We conduct the ablation study to compare different training strategies in our Fed_BVA framework. In this case, we use K=10ğ¾10K=10 clients with fraction F=1ğ¹1F=1 and local epoch E=5ğ¸5E=5. Other hyper-parameters and model architecture settings are the same as in our previous experiments. TableÂ 7 provides the performance of adversarial robustness using our Fed_BVA framework on MNIST with both IID and non-IID settings. It is observed that Fed_BVA with S1 has the best robustness in most cases compared to other heuristic training strategies S2 and S3. This indicates that bias and variance provide better direction to generate the adversarial examples for robust training. In contrast, detecting the adversarial examples with individual directions in S2 for each client might be sub-optimal.

S6.T8.table:
CIFAR-10 Source (FGSM attack) Source (PGD-20 attack)
Target R V X M R V X M
FedAvg 0.707 0.688 0.689 0.793 0.611 0.623 0.597 0.787
FedAvg_AT 0.742 0.710 0.720 0.808 0.695 0.670 0.661 0.808
Fed_Bias 0.740 0.703 0.715 0.799 0.690 0.667 0.654 0.799
Fed_Variance 0.738 0.704 0.719 0.810 0.677 0.656 0.648 0.809
Fed_BVA 0.744 0.706 0.722 0.809 0.693 0.669 0.664 0.809
EAT 0.821 0.806 0.815 0.823 0.819 0.808 0.813 0.822
EAT+Fed_BVA 0.828 0.808 0.817 0.828 0.825 0.809 0.812 0.829
references: Using black-box attack, we test the transferability of single-step attack (i.e., FGSMÂ (Goodfellow etÂ al., 2015)) and multi-step attack (i.e., PGDÂ (Kurakin etÂ al., 2017)) on various federated learning baseline models. For CIFAR-10 data set, we use ResNet18Â (He etÂ al., 2016), VGG11Â (Simonyan and Zisserman, 2015), XceptionÂ (Chollet, 2017), and MobileNetV2Â (Sandler etÂ al., 2018) as the source threat models for generating the single-step and multi-step adversarial examples. The black-box transfer attacking results are shown in TableÂ 8. We observe that without any adversarial training, FedAvg will suffer a maximum of 28%percent2828\% accuracy lost. For comparison, the robust federated learning model with global transmitted perturb samples (i.e., FedAvg_AT, Fed_Bias, Fed_Variance, Fed_BVA) will have increase robustness with a maximum of 23%percent2323\% accuracy drop on best baselines. For the computation-demanding local robust training methods (i.e., EAT and EAT+Fed_BVA), the maximum accuracy drop is only 3%percent33\%, respectively. Thus, it is straightforward to see that CIFAR-10 is more vulnerable to multi-step black-box adversarial attacks, but the local adversarial training methods could improve its robustness.
